awd_titl_txt: Self-Consistent Pulsar Magnetosphere Models:Macroscopic and Kinetic Models in the FERMI Era
awd_abstract_narration:
"Neutron stars" pack the mass of our Sun into a volume the size of Manhattan Island.  Because the density is so high, individual atomic nuclei crowd against each other and dissolve into neutrons.  In the 1960s, radio astronomers discovered pulsating radio sources.  Scientists soon realized that these "pulsars" are rapidly rotating neutron stars.  Their rotation periods range from a few seconds down to several thousandths of a second.  Magnetic fields more than a trillion times stronger than Earth's magnetic field are "frozen" into the neutron star, causing the pulsar radio emission.  The actual mechanism responsible for generating these radio signals has remained a mystery for nearly half a century.  Within the past decade, observations using the Fermi spacecraft have revealed more than 100 pulsars that emit pulsed gamma rays as well as pulsed radio signals.  The Investigators propose to compute detailed, three-dimensional numerical models for the behavior of electrons and positrons (positively charged electrons) in the space surrounding a pulsar.  Their research will attempt to produce the first self-consistent models of these so-called "pulsar magnetospheres."  The goal of this research is to enable scientists to predict the full spectrum of emission from a pulsar.  This will allow them to test the theory against observations.  If successful, these results will provide very strong Intellectual Impact from this work.  The Broader Impacts derive from the Investigators' activities to promote STEM education at several levels and from an innovative use of 3D printing to fabricate 3D models of pulsar magnetospheres.

As noted above, pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars, with enormously strong magnetic fields.  Astrophysicists quickly determined that such strong fields, "frozen" into rapidly rotating stars, would radiate electromagnetic energy at very high rates.  Observations from the Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope within the past decade have now detected gamma radiation from more than 100 pulsars, and preliminary work by the Investigators has demonstrated remarkable success in generating gamma-ray lightcurves that can be compared with these observations.  The proposed research will employ several up-to-date computer codes to attack the complicated problem of the pulsar emission mechanism through three-dimensional numerical simulations of pulsar magnetospheres.  The project will combine computations of the microscopic behavior of the plasma particles using particle-in-cell (PIC) methods with computations of the large-scale plasma behavior using magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations in an effort to develop fully self-consistent three-dimensional models.  The Intellectual Impact of the project results from the fact that, if it is successful, this work will constitute a valuable step forward in our understanding of pulsars.  The Broader Impacts of the work derive from the PIs' activities to promote STEM education at several levels and from innovative use of 3D printing to fabricate 3D models of pulsar magnetospheres.

por.por_cntn:
Pulsars are powerful electromagnetic machines powered by the rotation of magnetic fields of order 108 - 1013G, that mediate the conversion of their rotational energy into magnetohydronymical winds and at the same time accelerate particles to energies sufficiently high to produce GeV photons. Their electromagnetic emission is quite complex and ranges from the radio to at least the multi-GeV regime while recently pulsed emission that extends up to very high energies (i.e., multi-TeV) has been detected by MAGIC and VERITAS ground-based telescopes. Despite a fifty-year effort by a large number of researchers, the details of pulsar emission are still not fully understood. 

The Fermi Gamma-Ray Space Telescope has revolutionized the last decade the study of γ-ray pulsars since it increased the number of detected γ-ray pulsars by a factor of 40. Thus, Fermi has detected over 230 new γ-ray pulsars to date 117 of which are included in the Second Fermi Pulsar Catalog. 

In our studies, we developed and used state-of-the-art numerical codes to develop 3-dimensional global pulsar magnetosphere models. Our modeling highlighted the advantageous feedback between simulations and observations, contributing considerably to a growing understanding of the physics behind the pulsar γ-ray observations. We presented realistic macroscopic dissipative models and 3D global kinetic particle-in-cell models that reproduce, for the first time, a broad spectrum of the observed phenomenology (i.e., light-curves and spectra) as this is depicted in Fermi observations. The ultimate goal of these studies is the successful connection between the global macroscopic pulsar models, the microphysical processes for the radiation emission and particle creation, and the observations; such a combined study will provide unique insights into the physics of high-energy pulsar emission. A recent NASA News & Features release discusses the results of a series of our simulations (https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2018/pulsar-in-a-box-reveals-surprising-picture-of-a-neutron-star-s-surroundings).

Our model approach has demonstrated that simplicity is a valuable asset that can not only lead to a deep understanding of physical phenomena but also guide wisely numerical modeling. Thus, fundamental but simple theoretical considerations led to the discovery of a fundamental plane for the entire population of γ-ray pulsars. These discoveries provided not only a deeper understanding of the physics behind the pulsar γ-ray observations but also meaningful constraints on macroscopic and microscopic model parameters.

Moreover, our model predictions for the multiwavelength polarization, very high-energy emission, and MeV emission will be an essential point of reference for future space-based missions and ground-based telescopes.

In one of our studies we also identified a new, robust pulsar radio emission mechanism. We found that pair discharges in pulsar polar caps responsible for filling pulsar magnetospheres with dense electron-positron plasma generate coherent electromagnetic waves. These waves have superluminal phase velocities and cannot be absorbed by plasma, therefore, they should escape the magnetosphere and could be observed. The proposed mechanism significantly differs from the previous ad-hoc models and is consistent with modern models of pulsar magnetospheres.

We studied the process of pair formation in pulsar magnetospheres in great detail and found that the new self-consistent models of pulsar magnetospheres predict substantially higher efficiencies for the process of electron-positron pair creation than it was the case in the previous-generation models. We found that the maximum density of electron-positron plasma produced by pulsars is about a few ?105 of the characteristic plasma density (so-called Goldreich-Julian density).

We proposed a new model for repeating Fast Radio Bursts, where the radio emission is generated by magnetars (neutron stars with extremely high and twisted magnetic fields) during active phases knows as short bursts, if the twist of their magnetic field is not too large.

We disseminated our results to the general public through public lectures and videos and to undergraduate and graduate students through seminar and colloquium talks while we provided opportunities for research to high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students.
